about.title: About estimador.pt
about.subtitle: Independent, data-driven election forecasting for Portugal
about.contact: For questions, suggestions, or media inquiries, please contact us at
about.combiningExpertise: as an independent project combining Bayesian statistics, computational methods, and analysis of Portuguese electoral data.
about.missionDescription1: estimador.pt provides transparent, probabilistic forecasts for Portuguese elections. We believe democratic societies benefit when citizens have access to rigorous, unbiased analysis of electoral data—not just punditry and speculation.
about.missionDescription2: Our goal is to bring the standards of modern election forecasting—pioneered by projects like FiveThirtyEight and The Economist—to the Portuguese context, while adapting our methods to Portugal's multi-party proportional representation system.

whatWeDoList.forecasting: Bayesian models that combine polling data with historical patterns, accounting for uncertainty at every step
whatWeDoList.seatProjections: District-level analysis using the D'Hondt method to project how national vote shares translate to parliamentary seats
whatWeDoList.trendAnalysis: Gaussian Process models that track the evolution of party support over time, separating signal from noise
whatWeDoList.pollingAnalysis: Systematic estimation of pollster house effects—the consistent biases each polling firm shows toward certain parties

about.approachDescription1: We use Bayesian statistical methods that explicitly quantify uncertainty. Unlike point predictions, our forecasts produce probability distributions that reflect what we actually know—and don't know—about election outcomes.

approachPrinciples.transparency: Open methodology with detailed documentation of our models and assumptions
approachPrinciples.independence: No political affiliations, no partisan funding, no editorial pressure
approachPrinciples.accuracy: Continuous validation against actual election results, with honest assessment of forecast errors
approachPrinciples.accessibility: Presenting probabilistic forecasts in ways that general audiences can understand and use

about.limitationsDescription1: Election forecasting is inherently uncertain—that's why we present probabilities, not predictions. Our models account for several sources of uncertainty:

limitationsList.pollingError: Systematic and random polling error, including potential bias not captured by past elections
limitationsList.campaignDynamics: Late-breaking news and campaign events that can shift voter preferences
limitationsList.turnout: Differential turnout patterns that may not match historical patterns
limitationsList.regional: District-level variations that deviate from national trends

about.limitationsDescription2: A forecast showing a party with a 70% chance of winning most seats also means there's a 30% chance they won't. Our forecasts should be interpreted as informed probabilistic assessments, not certainties.

presidential.spaghettiDescription: Each line represents one possible simulation outcome. The spread of lines shows the uncertainty in our forecast - with ~35% undecided voters, outcomes remain highly uncertain.
presidential.trendDescription: Estimated support over time for the top candidates. Lines show the mean estimate, shaded bands show 50% and 95% credible intervals. Dots represent individual polls.
presidential.modelDescription: This forecast uses a Bayesian model that combines polling data with candidate-specific priors based on party affiliation. The model accounts for pollster house effects and uncertainty in voter preferences.
presidential.undecidedWarning: Important: Approximately 35% of voters remain undecided. This forecast shows declared voting intention only - actual results may differ significantly as undecided voters make their choices.
presidential.factor2: Candidate party affiliations and historical patterns
presidential.aboutDescription: Portuguese presidential elections use a two-round system. If no candidate receives more than 50% of votes in the first round, the top two candidates proceed to a second round. This forecast models declared voting intention based on available polling data.
presidential.runoffScenariosDescription: With a second round nearly certain, these are the most likely candidate matchups based on our simulations.
